p.seg: Ch. 1. 1. The summary of the Rules of Propriety says:
Always and in everything let there be reverence;
with the deportment grave as when one is thinking (deeply),
and with speech composed and definite.
This will make the people tranquil.
2. 2. Pride should not be allowed to grow;
the desires should not be indulged;
the will should not be gratified to the full;
pleasure should not be carried to excess.
3. 3. Men of talents and virtue can be familiar with others and yet respect them;
can stand in awe of others and yet love them.
They love others and yet acknowledge the evil that is in them.
They accumulate (wealth) and yet are able to part with it (to help the needy);
3. 4. When you find wealth within your reach, do not (try to) get it by improper means;
When you meet with calamity, do not (try to) escape from it by improper means.
Do not seek for victory in small contentions;
do not seek for more than your proper share.
3. 5. Do not positively affirm what you have doubts about;
4. 6. If a man be sitting, let him do so as a personator of the deceased;
if he be standing, let him do so (reverently), as in sacrificing.
4. 7. In (observing) the rules of propriety, what is right (for the time and the circumstances) should be followed.
In discharging a mission (to another state), its customs are to be observed.
4. 8. They are the rules of propriety,
that furnish the means of determining (the observances towards) relatives, as near and remote;
of settling points which may cause suspicion or doubt;
of distinguishing where there should be agreement, and where difference;
5. 9. According to those rules,
one should not (seek to) please others in an improper way,
nor be lavish of his words.
5. 10. According to them,
one does not go beyond the definite measure,
or encroach on or despise others,
nor is fond of (presuming) familiarities.
5. 11. To cultivate one's person and fulfil one's words
is called good conduct.
When the conduct is (thus) ordered, and the words are accordant with the right course,
5. 12. I have heard that it is in accordance with those rules that one should be chosen by others (as their model);
I have not heard of his choosing them (to take him as such).
I have heard in the same way of (scholars) coming to learn;
I have not heard of (the master) going to teach.
5. 13. The course (of duty), virtue, benevolence and righteous ness
cannot be fully carried out without the rules of propriety;
5. 14. nor are training and oral lessons
for the rectification of manners complete;
5. 15. nor can the clearing up of quarrels
and discriminating in disputes be accomplished;
5. 16. nor can (the duties between) ruler and minister, high and low, father and son, elder brother and younger, be determined;
5. 17. nor can students for office and (other) learners,
in serving their masters, have an attachment for them;
5. 18. nor can majesty and dignity be shown
in assigning the different places at court, in the government of the armies,
and in discharging the duties of office so as to secure the operation of the laws;
5. 19. nor can there be the (proper) sincerity and gravity
in presenting the offerings to spiritual beings
on occasions of supplication, thanksgiving, and the various sacrifices.
5. 21. The parrot can speak
and yet is nothing more than a bird;
the ape can speak,
and yet is nothing more than a beast.
Here now is a man who observes no rules of propriety;
father and son might have the same mate.
5. 22. Therefore, when the sages arose,
they framed the rules of propriety in order to teach men,
and cause them, by their possession of them,
6. 23. In the highest antiquity they prized (simply conferring) good;
in the time next to this, giving and repaying was the thing attended to.
And what the rules of propriety value is that of reciprocity.
If I give a gift and nothing comes in return,
that is contrary to propritey;
if the thing comes to me, and I give nothing in return,
that is also contrary to propriety.
6. 24. If a man observe the rules of propriety, he is in a condition of security;
if he do not, he is in one of danger.
Hence is the saying,
6. 25. Propriety is seen
in humbling oneself and giving honour to others.
Even porters and peddlers
are sure to display this giving honour (in some cases);
how much more should the rich and noble do so (in all)!
6. 26. when the rich and noble know to love propriety,
they do not become propud nor dissolute.
When the poor and mean know to love propriety,
7. 27. When one is ten years old, we call him a boy;
he goes (out) to school.
When he is twenty, we call him a youth;
he is capped.
When he is thirty, we say, 'He is at his maturity;'
he has a wife.
When he is forty, we say, 'He is in his vigour;'
he is employed in office.
When he is fifty, we say, 'He is getting grey;'
he can discharge all the duties of an officer.
When he is sixty, we say, 'He is getting old;'
he gives directions and instructions.
When he is seventy, we say, 'He is old;'
he delegates his duties to others.
At eighty or ninety, we say of him, 'He is very old.'
When he is seven, we say he is an object of pitying love.
Such a child and one who is very old,
though they may be chargeable with crime,
are not subjected to punishment.
At a hundred, he is called a centenarian,
7. 28. A great officer, when he is seventy, should resign (his charge of) affairs.
7. 29. If he be not allowed to resign
there must be given him a stool and staff.
When travelling on service, he must have the attendance of his wife;
and when going to any other state,
he will ride in an easy carriage.
7. 30. (In another state) he will style himself 'the old man;'
in his own state, he will call himself by his name.
7. 31. When from another they ask (about his state),
1. 1. In going to take councel with an elder,
one must carry a stool and a staff with him (for the elder's use).
When the elder asks a question,
to reply without acknowledging one's incompetency and (trying to) decline answering,
is contrary to propriety.
2. 2. For all sons it is the rule:
-in winter, to warm (the bed for their parents), and to cool it in summer;
in the evening, to adjust everything (for their repose), and to inquire (about their health) in the morning;
3. 3. Whenever a son,
having recieved the three (first) gifts (of the ruler), declines (to use) the carriage and horses,
the people of the hamlets and smaller districts, and of the larger districts and neighbourhoods, will call him filial;
brothers and relatives, both by consanguinity and affinity, will proclaim him loving;
his friends who are fellow-officers will proclaim him virtuous;
4. 4. When he sees an intimate friend of his father,
not to presume to go forward to him without being told to do so;
nor to retire without being told;
nor to address him
without being questioned:
4. 5. A son,
when he is going abroad, must inform (his parents where he is going);
when he returns, he must present himself before them.
Where he travels must be in some fixed (region);
what he engages in must be some (reputable) occupation.
4. 6. In ordinary conversation (with his parents), he does not use the term 'old' (with reference to them).
4. 7. He should serve one twice as old as himself as he serves his father,
one ten years older than himself as an elder brother;
with one five years older he should walk shoulder to shoulder, but (a little) behind him.
4. 8. When five are sitting together,
4. 9. A son
should not occupy the south-west corner of the appartment,
nor sit in the middle of the mat (which he occupies alone),
nor walk in the middle of the road,
nor stand in the middle of the doorway.
4. 10. He should not take the part of regulating the (quantity of) rice and other viands at an entertainment.
4. 11. He should not act as personator of the dead at sacrifice.
4. 12. He should be (as if he were) hearing (his parents) when there is no voice from them,
and seeing them when they are not actually there.
4. 13. He should not ascend a height,
nor approach the verge of a depth;
he should not indulge in reckless reviling
or derisive laughing.
4. 13. A filial son will not do things in the dark,
nor attempt hazardous undertakings,
fearing lest he disgrace his parents.
4. 14. While his parents are alive,
he will not promise a friend to die (with or for him),
4. 15. A son,
while his parents are alive,
will not wear a cap or (other) article of dress, with a white border.
4. 16. An orphan son, taking his father's place,
5. 17. A boy should never be allowed to see an instance of deceit.
5. 18. A lad should not wear a jacket of fur nor the skirt
He must stand straight and square
and not incline his head in hearing.
5. 19. When an elder is holding him with the hand,
he should hold the elder's hand with both his hands.
When the elder has shifted his sword to his back and is speaking to him with the side of his face bent down,
5. 20. When he is following his teacher,
he should not quit the road to speak with another person.
When he meets his teacher on the road,
he should hasten forward to him,
and stand with his hands joined across his breast.
If the teacher speak to him, he will answer;
5. 21. When, following an elder, they ascend a level height,
he must keep his face towards the quarter to which the elder is looking.
5. 22. When one has ascended the wall of a city, he should not point,
5. 23. When he intends to go to a lodging-house,
let it not be with the feeling that he must get whatever he asks for.
5. 24. When about to go up to the hall (of a house),
he must raise his voice.
When outside the door there are two (pairs of) shoes,
if voices be heard, he enters;
if voices be not heard, he will not enter.
5. 25. When about to enter the door,
he must keep his eyes cast down.
As he enters, he should (keep his hands raised as high as if he were) bearing the bar of the door.
In looking down or up, he should not turn (his head).
If the door were open, he should leave it open;
if it were shut, he should shut it again.
If there be others (about) to enter after him,
while he (turns to) shut the door, let him not do so hastily.
5. 26. Let him not tread on the shoes (left outside the door),
nor stride across the mat (in going to take his seat);
but let him hold up his dress, and move hastily to his corner (of the mat).
6. 27. A great officer or (other) officer should go out or in at the ruler' doors,
on the right of the middle post
7. 28. Whenever (a host has recieved and) is entering with a guest,
at every door he should give place to him.
When the guest arives at the inermost door (or that leading to the feast-room),
the host will ask to be allowed to enter first and arange the mats.
Having done this, he will come out to recieve the guest,
who will refuse firmly (to enter first).
The host having made a low bow to him, they will enter (together).
7. 29. When they have entered the door, the host moves to the right,
and the guest to the left,
the former going to the steps on the east,
and the latter to those on the west.
If the guest be of a lower rank,
he goes to the steps of the host (as if to follow him up them).
The host firmly declines this,
and he returns to the other steps on the west.
7. 30. They then offer to each other the preceedence in going up,
but the host commences first,
followed (immediatley) by the other.
They bring their feet together on every step,
thus ascending by successive paces.
He who ascends by the steps on the east should move his right foot first,
7. 31. Outside the curttain or screen (a visitor) should not walk with the formal hasty steps,
nor above in the hall,
nor when carrying the symbol of jade.
Above, in the raised hall, the footprints should be alongside each other,
but below it free and separate.
In the apartment the elbows should not be held out like wings when bowing.
7. 32. When two (equals) are sitting side by side, they do not have their elbows extended crosswise.
One should not kneel in handing something to a (superior) standing,
1.1. In all cases of (a lad's) carrying away the dirt that has been swept up from the presence of an elder,
it is the rule that he (place) the brush on the basket,
keeping his sleeve before it as he retires.
The dust is not allowed to reach the elder,
1.2. He carries the (elder's) mat in his arms like the cross-beam of a shadoof.
1.3. If it be a mat to sit on, he will ask in what direction (the elder) is going to turn his face;
if it be to sleep on, in what direction he is going to turn his feet.
1.4. If a mat
face the south or the north,
the seat on the west is accounted that of honour;
If it face the east or the west,
the seat on the south.
2.5. Except in the case of guests who are getting there (simply) to eat and drink,
in spreading the mats
a space of ten cubits should be left between them.
2.6. When the host kneels to adjust the mats(of a visitor),
the other should kneel and keep hold of them, declining (the honour).
When the visitor (wishes to) remove one or more,
the host should firmly decline to permit him to do so.
When the visitor steps on his mats,
(the host) takes his seat.
2. 7. If the host have not put some question,
the visitor should not begin the conversation. [bring a matter up]
3. 8. When (a pupil) is about to go to his mat,
he should not look discomposed.
With his two hands he should hold up his lower garment, so that the bottom of it may be a cubit from the ground.
His clothes should not hang loosely about him,
nor should there be any huried movements of his feet.
3. 9. If any writing or tablets of his master, or his lute or citern be in the way,
he should kneel down and remove them,
3. 10. When sitting and doing nothing, he should keep quite at the back (of his mat);
when eating, quite at the front of it.
He should sit quietly
and keep a watch on his countenance.
If there be any subject on which the elder has not touched,
let him not introduce it irregularly.
3. 11. Let him keep his deportment correct,
and listen respectfully.
Let him not appropriate (to himself) the words (of others),
nor (repeat them) as (the echo does the) thunder.
If he must (adduce proofs), let them be from antiquity,
3. 12. when sitting by his side,
nd the teacher puts a question,
(the learner) should not reply till (the other) has finished.
3. 13. When requesting (instruction) on the subject of his studies, (the learner) should rise;
when requesting further information, he should rise.
3. 14. When his father calls, (a youth) should not (merely) answer 'yes',
nor when his teacher calls.
3. 15. When one is sitting in attendance on another whom he honours and revers,
he should not allow any part of his mat to keep them apart,
nor will he rise when he sees others (come in) of the same rank as himself.
3. 16. When the torches come, he should rise;
and also when the viands come in,
3. 17. The torches should not (e allowed to burn) till their ends can be seen.
3. 18. Before an honoured visitor we should not shout (even) at a dog.
4. 20. When one is sitting on attendance on another of superior character or rank,
and that other yawns or streches himself,
or lays hold of his staff or shoes,
or looks towards the sun to see if it be early or late,
he should ask to be allowed to leave.
4. 21. In the same position,
if the superior man put a question on a new subject,
he should rise up in giving his reply.
4. 22. Similarly,
if there come some one saying (to the superior man),
'I wish, when you have a little leisure,
to report to you,'
he should withdraw to the left or right and wait.
4. 23. Do not listen with the head inclined on one side,
nor answer with a loud sharp voice,
nor look with a dissolute leer,
nor keep the body in a slouching position.
4. 24. Do not saunter about with a haughty gait,
or stand with one foot raised.
Do not sit with your knees wide apart,
nor sleep on your face.
4. 25. Have your hair gathered up, and do not use any false hair.
4. 26. Let not the cap be laid aside;
nor let the chest be bared, (even) when one is toiling hard;
5. 27. When (going to) sit in attendance one an elder,
(a visitor) should not go up to the hall with his shoes on,
nor should he presume to take them off in front of the steps.
5. 28. (When any single visitor is leaving), he will go to his shoes,
kneel down and take them up,
and then move to one side.
5. 29. (When the visitors retire in a body) with their faces towards the elder, (they stand) by the shoes,
which they then, kneeling, remove (some distance),
6. 30. When two men are sitting or standing together,
do not join them as a third.
When two are standing together,
another should not pass between them.
6. 31. Male and female should not sit together (in the same apartment),
nor have the same rack for their clothes,
nor use the same towel or comb,
nor let their hands touch in giving or recieving.
6. 32. A sister-in-law and brother-in-law do not interchange inquiries (about each other).
none of the concubines in a house should be employed to wash the lower garment (of a son).
6. 33. Outside affairs should not be talked of inside the treshold (of the women's appartments),
nor inside (or women's) affair outside it.
6. 34. When a young lady is promised in marriage,
she wears the strings (hanging down to her neck);
and unless there be some great occasion,
o (male) enters the door of her apartment.
6. 35. When a married aunt, or sister, or daughter
returns home (on a visit),
no brother (of the family) should sit with her on the same mat
or eat with her from the same dish.
6. 36. Male and female, without the intervention of the matchmaker,
do not know each other's name.
Unless the marriage presents have been recieved,
there should be no communication or affection between them.
6. 37. Hence the day and month (of the marriage) should be announced to the ruler,
and to the spirits (of ancestors) with purification and fasting;
and (the bridegroom) should make a feast, and invite (his friends) in the district and neighbourhood, and his fellow officers:
6. 38. One must not marry a wife of the same with himself.
Hence, in buying a concubine, if he does not know her surname,
he must consult the tortoise-shell about it.
6. 39. With the son of a widow,
unless he be of acknowledged distinction,
7. 40. When one congratuates (a friend) on his marrying,
his messenger says,
'So and So has sent me.
Having heard that you are having guests,
he has sent me with this present.'
8. 41. Goods and wealth are not to be expected from the poor in their discharge of the rules of propriety;
9. 42. In giving a name to a son, it should not be that of a state,
nor of a day in the month,
nor of any hidden ailment,
nor of a hill or river.
9.43. Sons and daughters should have their (relative) ages distinguished.
9.44. A son at twenty
is capped, and recieves his appellation.
9. 45. Before his father
a son should be called by his name,
and before his ruler
a minister.
9. 46. When daughter is promised in marriage,
10. 47. The rules for bringing in the dishes for an entertainment are the following:
- The meat cooked on the bones is set on the left, and the sliced meat on the right;
the rice is placed on the left of the parties on the mat,
and the soup on their right;
the minced and roasted meat are put outside (the chops and sliced meat),
and the pickles and sauces inside;
the onions and steamed onions succeed to these,
and the drinks and syrups are on the right.
When slices of dried and spiced meat are put down,
10. 48. If a guest be of lower rank (than his entertainer),
he should take up the rice, rise and decline (the honour he is recieving).
The host then rises and refuses to allow the guest (to retire).
After this the guest will resume his seat.
10. 49. When the host leads on the guests
to present an offering (to the father of cookery),
they will begin with the dishes which were first brought in.
Going on from the meat cooked on the bones
they will offer all (the other dishes).
10. 50. After they have eaten three times,
the host will lead on the guests to take of the sliced meat
from which they will go on to all the other dishes.
10. 51. A guest should not rinse his mouth with spirits
11. 52. When (a youth) is in attendance on an elder at a meal,
if the host give anything to him with his own hand,
he should bow to him and eat it.
If he do not so give him anything,
he should eat without bowing.
12. 53. When eating with others from the same dishes, one should not try to eat (hastily) to satiety.
13. 54. do not roll the rice into a ball;
do not bolt down the various dishes;
do not swill down (the soup).
13. 55. Do not make a noise in eating;
do not crunch the bones with the teeth;
do not put back fish you have been eating;
do not throw the bones to the dogs;
do not snatch (at what you want).
13. 56. Do not spread out the rice (to cool);
do not use chopsticks in eating millet.
13. 57. Do not (try to) gulp down soup with vegetables in it,
nor add condiments to it;
do not keep picking the teeth,
nor swill down the sauces.
If a guest add condiments,
the host will apologize for not having had the soup prepared better.
If he swill down the sauces,
the host will apologize for his poverty.
13. 58. Meat that is wet (and soft) may be divided with the teeth,
but dried flesh cannot be so dealth with.
Do not bolt roast meat in large pieces.
14. 59. When they have done eating,
the guests will kneel in front (of the mat),
and (begin to) remove the (dishes) of rice and sauces to give them to the attendants.
The host will then rise and decline this service from the guests,
15. 60. If a youth is in attendance on, and drinking with, and elder,
when the (cup of) spirits is brought to him, he rises,
bows and (goes to) receive it at the place where the spirit-vase is kept.
The elder refuses (to alow him to do so),
when he erturns to the mat, and (is prepared) to drink.
The elder (meantime) lifts (his cup);
but until he has emptied it,
16. 61. When an elder offers a gift,
either a youth, nor one of mean condition, presumes to decline it.
17. 62. When a fruit is given by the ruler and in his presence,
if there be a kernel in it, (the reciever) should place it in his bosom.
18. 63. When one is attending the ruler at a meal,
and the ruler gives him anything that is left,
if it be in a vessel that can be easily scoured, he does not transfer it (to another of his own);
but from any other vessel he should transfer it.
19. 64. Portions of (such) food should not be used as offerings (to the departed).
A father should not use them in offering to a (deceased) son,
20. 65. When one is attending an elder and (called to) share with him (at a feast),
though the viands may be double (what is necessary), he should not (seek) to decline them.
If he take his seat (only) as the companion of another (for whom it has been prepared), he should not decline them.
21. 66. If the soup be made with vegetables, chopsticks should be used;
22. 67. He who pares a melon for the son of Heaven should divide it into four parts and then into eight,
and cover them with a napkin of fine linen.
for the ruler of a state, he should divide it into four parts,
and cover them with a coarse napkin.
To a great officer he should (present the four parts) uncovered.
An inferior officer should recieve it (simply) with the stalk cut away.
1. 1.When a father or mother is ill,
(a young man) who has been capped should not use his comb,
nor walk with his elbows stuck out,
nor speak of idle topics,
nor take his lute or citern in hand.
He should not eat of (different) meats till his taste is changed,
nor drink till his looks are changed.
He should not laugh s0 as to show his teeth,
nor be angry till he breaks forth in reviling.
When the illness is gone, he may resume his former habits.
1. 2. He who is sad and anxious should sit with his mat spread a part from others;
2. 3. When heavy rains have fallen,
one should not present fish or tortoises (to a superior).
2. 4. He who is presenting a bird should turn its head on one side;
if it be a tame bird, this need not be done.
2. 5. He who is presenting a carriage and horses should carry in his hand (to the hall) the whip, and strap for mounting by.
2. 6. He who is presenting a suit of mail should carry the helmet (to the hall).
He who is presenting a staff should hold it by its end.
2. 7. He who is presenting a captive should hold him by the right sleeve.
2. 8. He who is presenting grain unhulled should carry with him the left side of the account (of the quantity);
if the hull be off, he should carry with him a measure-drum.
2. 9. He who is presenting cooked food, should carry with him the sauce and lpickles for it.
2. 11. In every case of giving a bow to another,
if it be bent, the (string of) sinew should be kept upwards;
but if unbent, the horn.
(The giver) should with his right hand grasp the end of the bow,
and keep his left under the middle of the back.
The (parties, without regard to their rank as) high and low, (bow to each other) till the napkins (at their girdles) hang down (to the ground).
If the host (wish to) bow (still lower),
the other moves to one side
to avoid the salutation.
The host then takes the bow,
standing to the left of the other.
Putting his hand under that of the visitor, he lays hold of the middle of the back,
having his face in the same direction as the other;
2. 12. He who ois giving a sword should do so with the hilt on his left side.
2. 13. He who is giving a spear with one hook should do so with the metal end of the shaft in the front,
and the sharp end behind.
2. 15. He who is giving a stool or a staff should first wipe it.
2. 16. He who is presenting a horse or a sheep should lead it with his right hand.
2. 17. He who is presenting a dog should lead it with his left hand.
2. 18. He who is carrying a bird (as his present of introduction) should do so with the head to the left.
2. 19. For the ornamental covering of a lamb or a goose, an embroidered cloth should be used.
2. 20. He who recieves a pearl or a piece of jade should do so with both his hands.
2. 21. He who recieves a bow or a sword should do so (having his hands covered) with his sleeves.
2. 22. He who has drunk from a cup of jade should not (go on to) shake it out.

2. 23. Whenever friendly messages are about to be sent, with the present of a sword or bow, or of (fruit, flesh, and other things, wrapped in) matting or rushes, with grass mats, and in baskets, round or square,
(the messenger) has these things (carried with him, when he goes) to recieve his commission,
2. 24. Whenever one is charged with a mission by his ruler,
after he has recieved from him his orders
and (heard all) he has to say, he should not remain over the night in his house.
2. 25. When a message from the ruler comes (to a minister),
the latter should go out and bow (to the bearer), in acknowledgement of the honour of it.
When the meseenger is about to return,
(the other) must bow to him (again), and escort him outside the gate.
2. 26. If (a minister) send a message to his ruler,
he must wear his court-robes when he communicates ti to the bearer;
and on his return,
3. 27. T accuire extensive information and remember retentively, whild (at the same time) he is modest;
to do earnestly what is good, and not become weary in so doing:
- theses are the characteristics of him whom we cll the superior man.
3. 28. A superior man does not accept everything by which another would expres joy in him,
or his devotion to him;
4. 29. A rule of propriety says,
'A superior man may carry his grandson in his arms, but not his son.'
This tells us that a grandson may be the personator of his deceased granfather (at sacrifices)
but a son cannot be so for his father.
4. 30. When a great officer of (other) officer sees
one who is to personate the dead (on his way to the ancestral temple),
he should dismount from his carriage to him.
The ruler himself, when he recognizes him,
should do the same.
The personator (at the same time) must bow forward to the cross-bar.
5. 31. One who is fasting (in preparation for a sacrifice) should neither listen to music nor condole with mourners.
6. 32. According to the rules for the period of mourning (for a father),
(a son) should not emaciate himself till the bones appear,
nor let his seeing and hearing be affected (by his privations).
He should not go up to, nor descend from, the hall by the steps on the east (which his father used),
6. 33. Acoording to the same rules,
if he have a scab on his head, he should wash it;
if he have a sore on his body, he should bathe it.
If he be ill, he should drink spirits, and eat flesh,
returning to his former (abstinence) when he is better.
If he make himself unable to perform his mourning duties,
that is like being unkind and unfilial.
6. 34. If he be fifty, he should not allow himself to be reduced (by his abstinence) very much;
and if he be sixty, not at all.
At seventy, he will only wear the unhemmed dress of sackcloth,
and will drink and eat flesh,
7. 35. Intercourse with the living (will be continued) in the future;
intercourse with the dead (friend) was a thing of the past.
7. 36. He who knowsthe living should send (a message of) condolence;
and he who knew the dead(a message also of his) grief.
He who knows the living, and did ot know the dead,
will send his condolence without (that expression of) his grief;
he who knew the dead, and does not know the living,
8. 37. He who is condoling with one who has mourning rites in hand, and is not able to assist him with a gift,
should put no question about his expenditure.
He who is enquiring after another that is ill, and is not abl to send (anything to him),
should not ask him what he would like.
He who sees (a traveller), and is not able to lodge him,
hould not ask where he is stopping.
8. 38. He who would ocnfer something on another should not say, 'Some and take it;'
9. 39. When one goes to a burying-ground, he should not get up on any of the graves.
When assisting at an interment, one should (join in) holding the rope attached to the coffin.
9. 40. In a house of mourning, one should not laugh.
9. 41. In order to bow to another, one should not leavehis own place.
9. 42. When one sees ata distance a coffin with the corpse in it, he should not sing.
When he enters among the nmourners, he should not keep his arms stuck out.
When eating (with others), he should not sigh.
9. 43. when there are mourning rites in his neighbourhood,
one should not accompany his pestle with his voice.
When there is a body shrouded and coffined in his village,
one should not sing in the lanes.
9. 44. When going to a burying-ground, one should not sing,
nor on the same day when he has wailed (with mourners).
9. 45. When accompanying a funeral, one should not take a by-path.
When taking part in the act of interment, one should not (try to) avoid mud or pools.
When presenting himself at any mourning rite, one should have a sad countenance.
When holding the rope, one should not laugh.
9. 46. when present on an occasion of joy, one shuld not sigh.
9. 47. When wearing his coat of mail and helmet,
one's countenance should say, 'who dares meddle with me?'

10. 49. Where the ruler of a state lays hold of the cross-bar,
and bends forward to it, a great officer will descent from his carriage.
Where a great officer lays hold of the bar and bends forward,
another oficer will descend.
10. 50. The rules of ceremony do not go down to the common people.
10. 51. The penal statutes do not go up to the great officers.
10. 52. Men who have suffered punishment should not (be allowed to) be by the side of the ruler.
1. 1. A fighting chariot has no cross-board to assist its occupnats in bowing;
isn a war chariot the banner is fully displayed;
1.2. A recorder should carry with him his implements for writhing;
his subordinates the (recorded) words (of former covnants and other docments).
1. 3. When there is water in front,
the flag with the green bird on it should be displayed.
1. 4. When there is (a cloud of) dust in front,
that with the screaming kites.
1. 5. for chariots and horsemen,
that with the geese in flight.
1. 6. For a body of troops,
that with a tiger's (skin).
1. 7. For a beast of prey,
that with a leopard's (skin).
1. 8. On the march
the banner with the Red Bird should be in front;
that with the Dark Warrior behind;
that with the Azurwe Dragon on the left; and that with the White Tiger on the right;
that with the Pointer of the Northern Bushel should be reared aloft (in the center of the host):
--all to excite and direct the fury (of the troops).
1. 9. There are rules for advancing and retreating;
there are the various arrangements on the left and the right,
2. 10. With the enemy who has slayn his father,
one should not live under the same heaven.
With the enemy who has slain his brother,
one should never have his sword to seek (to deal vengeance).
With the enemy who has slain his intimate friend,
one should not live in the same state (without seeking to slay him).
3. 11. Many ramparts in the country round and near (a capital)
are a disgrace to its high ministers and great officers.
Where the wide and open country
is greatly neglected and uncultivated,
4. 12. When taking part in a sacrifice, one should not show indifference.
4. 13. When sacrificial robes are worn out, they should be burnt:
sacrificial vessels in the same condition should be buried,
as should the tortoise-shells and divining stalks,
and a victim that has died.
4. 14. All who take part with the ruler in a sacrifice
5. 15. When the ceremony of wailing is over, a son should no longer speak of his deceased father by his name.
The rules do not require the avoiding of names merely similar in sound to those not to be spoken.
When (a parent had) a double name, the avoiding of either term(used singly) is not required.
5. 16. While his plarents (are alive), and a son is able to serve them,
he should not utter the names of his grandparents;
when he can no longer serve his plarents (through their death),
he need not avoid the names of his grandparents.
5. 17. Names that would not be spoken (in his own family) need not be avoided (by a great officer) before his ruler;
in the great officer's, however, the names proper to be supressed by the ruler should nt be spoken.
5. 18. In (reading) the books of poetry and history, there need be no avoiding of names,
nor in writing compositions.
5. 19. In the ancestral temple there is no such avoiding.
5. 20. Even in his presence,
a minister need not avoid
the names improper to be spoken by the ruler's wife.
The names to be avoided by a wife need not be unspoken outside the door of the harem.
The names of parties for whom mourning is worn (only) nine months or five months are not to be avoided.
5. 21. When one is crossing the boundaries (of a state), he should ask what are the prohibitory laws;
when he has fairly entered it, he should ask about its customs;
6. 22. External undertakings should be commenced on the odd days,
and internal on the even.
6. 23. In all cases of divining about a day, wether by the tortiose-shell or the stalks,
if it be beyond the decade, it is said, 'on such and such a distant day,'
and if within the decade, 'on such and such a near day.'
For matters of mourning a distant day is preferred;
for festive matters a near day.
6. 24. It is said,
'For the day
we depend on thee, O great Tortoise-shell, which dost give the regular indications;
we depend on you, O great Divining Stalks, which give the regular indications.'
6. 25. Divination by the shell or the stalks should not go beyond three times.
6. 26. The shell and the stalks should not be both used onthe same subject.
6. 27. Divination by the shell is called pu;
by the stalks, shih.

stand in awe of their laws and orders;
the methods (also) by which they made them determine their perplexities

7. 28. When the ruler's carriage is about to have the horses put to it,
the driver should stand before them, whip in hand.
7. 29. When they are yoked,
he will inspect the linch pin, and report that the carriage is ready.
7. 30. (Coming out again), he should shake the dust from his clothes, and mount on the right side,
taking hold of the second strap.
He should (then) kneel in the carriage.
7. 31. Holding his whip, and taking the reins separately,
will drive the horses on five paces, and then stop.
7. 32. When the ruler comes out and approaches the carriage,
the driver should take all the reins in ine hand, and with the other hand the strap to him.
The attendants should then retire out of the way.
7. 33. They should follow quickly as the carriage drives on.
When it reaches the great gate,
he ruler will lay his hand on that of the driver (that he may drive gently) and, looking round,
will order the warrior for the seat on the right to come into the carriage.
In passing through the gates (of a city) or village, and crossing the water channels,
8. 34. In all cases it is the rule
for the diriver to hand the strap (to the person about to mount the carriage).
If the driver be of lower rank (than himself)
that other recieves it.
If this be not the case,
he should not do so.
8. 35. If the driver be of the lower rank,
the other should (still) lay his own hand on his (as if to stop him).
If this be not the case (and the driver will insist on handing it),
the other should take hold of the strap below (the driver's hand).
9. 36. A guest's carriage does not enter the gerat gate;
a woman does not stand u in her carriage;
dogs and horses are not taken u to the hall.
10. 37. Hence, the ruler bows forward to his cross-board to (an old man of) yellow hair;
he dismounts (and wlaks on foot) past the places of his high nobles (in the audience court).
He does not gallop the horses of his carriage in the capital;
and should bow forward on entering a village.
10. 38. when called by the ruler's order,
though through a man of low rank,
10. 39. A man in armour does not bow,
he makes obeisance indeed, but it is a restrained obeisance.
10. 40. When the carriage of a deceased ruler is following at his interment, the place on the left sould be vacant.
When (any of his ministers on other occasoins) are riding in (any of) the ruler's carriages,
they do not presume to leave the seat on the left vacant,
but he who occupies it should bend forward to the cross-board.
10. 41. A charioteer driving a woman
should keep his left hand advanced (with the reins in it),
and his right hand behind him.
10. 42. When driving the ruler of a state,
(the charioteer) should have his right hand advanced,
with the left kept behind and the head bent down.
10. 43. In his carriage one should not cough loudly,
nor point with his hand in an iregular way.
10. 44. Standing (in his carriage) one should look (forward only) to the distance of five revolutions of the wheels.
Bending forward, he should (do so only till he) sees the tails of the horses.
He should not turn his head round beyond the (line of the) naves.
10. 45.In the (streets of the) capital one should touch the horses gently with the brush-end of the switch.
He should not urge the to their speed.
10. 46. The ruler of a state should bend towards the cross-board when he meets a sacrificial victim,
and dismount (in passing) the ancestral temple.
A great officer or (other) officer should descend (when he comes to) the ruler's gate,
and bend forward to the ruler's horses.
10. 47. (a minister) riding in one of the ruler's carriages
must wear his court robes.
He should have his whip in the carriage with him, (but not use it).
He should not presume to have the strap handed to him.
In his place to the left, he should bow forward to the cross-board.
10. 48. (An officer) walking the ruler's horses
should do so in the middle of the road.
If he trample on their forage,
he should be punished,
and also
1. 1. When a thing is carried with both hands, it should be held on a level with the heart;
when with one hand, on a level with the girdle.
1. 2. An article belonging to the son of Heaven should be held higher than the heart;
one belonging to a ruler of a state, on a level with it;
one belonging to a Great officer, lower than it;

though it may belight, he should seem unable to sustain it.
In the case
of a piece of silk, or a rank-symbol of jade, square or round,

He should not litf his feet in walking,

Where his lord has his pendants hanging at his side,
his should be hanging down in front;
where his lord has them hanging in front,
his should descend to the ground.
1. 5. When one is holding any symbol of jade (to present it),
if it be on a mat, he leave it so exposed;
2. 6. The ruler of a state should not call by their names his highest ministers, nor the two noble ladies of her surname, who accompanied his wife to the harem.
A Great officer should not call in that way an officer who had been employed by his father, nor the niece and younger sister of his wife (members of his harem).
(Another) officer should not call by name the steward of his family, nor his principal concubine.

should not presume to spea of himself as 'I, the little son.'
The son of a Great officer or (other) officer(of a state)
should not presume to speak of himself as 'I, the inheriting son, so-and-so.'

and say,

should not seek to change his (old) customs.
His ceremonies in sacrifice,
his dress during the period of mourning,
and his position in the wailing and weeping,
will all be according to the fashions of his former (state).
He will carefully study its rules,
and carry them exactly into practice.
5. 11. (But) if he (or his descendants) have been away from the state for three generations,

(Even) after three generations,
if his dignity and emoulments be not reckkoned to him in the court,
and his outgoings and incomings are (no longer) announced in the state,
it is only on the day of his elevation (to official rank)
that he should follow the ways of his new state.
6. 12. A superior man, when left an orphan, will not change his name.
Nor will he in such a case, if he suddenly become noble,
frame an honorary title for his father.
7. 13. When occupied with the duties of mourning,
and before the interment of (a parent),
(a son) should study the ceremonies of mourning;
and after the interment,
those of sacrifice.
When the mourning is over, let him resume his usual ways, a
nd study the pieces of music.
7. 14. When occupied with the duties of mourning, one should not speak of music.
When sacrificing, one should not speak of what is inauspicious.
8. 15. For one to have to dust his (collection of) written tablets, or adjust them before the ruler,
is a punishable offence;
and also is it
to have the divining stalks turned upside down or the tortioise-shell turned on one side, before him.
8. 16. One should not enter the ruler's gate,
(carrying with him) a tortoise-shell or divining stalks,
a stool or a staff,
mats or (sun-)shades,
or having his upper and lower garments both of white
or in a single robe of fine or coarse hempen cloth.
Nor should he do so
in rush sandals,
or with the skirts of his lower garment tucked in at his waist,
or in the cap worn in the shorter periods of mourning.
Nor, unless announcement of it has been made (and permission given), 衰， can one take in
the square tablets with the written (lists of articles for a funeral),
or the frayed sackcloth,
or the coffin and its furniture.
9. 18. When a superior man, (high in rank), is about to engage in building,
the ancestral temple should have his first attention,
the stables and arsenal the next,
and the residence the last.
In all preparations of things by (the head of) a clan,
the vessels of sacrifice should have the first place;
the victims supplied from his revenue, the next;
and the vessels for use at the meals, the last.
Those who have no revenue from lands
do not provide vessels for sacrifice.
Those who have such revenue
first prepare their sacrificial dresses.
A superior man, though poor,
will not sell his vessels of sacrifice;
though suffering from cold,
he will not wear his sacrificial robes;
in building a house,
10. 19. A Great or other officer, leaving his state,
should not take his vessels of sacrifice with him across the boundary.
The former will leave his vessels for the time with another Great officer,
and the latter with another officer.
10. 20. A Great or other officer, leaving his state,
on crossing the boundary,
should prepare for an altar, and wail there, looking in the direction of the state.
He should wear his upper garment
and lower,
and his cap, all of white;
remove his ornamental collar,
wear shoes of untanned leather,
have a covering of white (dog's-fur) for his cross-board,
and leave his horses' manes undressed.
He should not trim his nails or beard,
nor make an offering at his (spare) meals.
He should not say to any one that he is not chargeable with guilt,
nor have any of his women approach him.
10. 21. When a Great officer or other officer has an interview with the ruler of the state (to whom he has been sent),
if the ruler be condoling with him on the toils oof his journey,
he should withdraw on one side to avoid (the honour),
and then bow twice with his head to the ground.
If the ruler meet him (outside the gate) and bokw to him,
he should withdraw on one side to avoid (the honour),
and not presume to return the bow.
10. 22. When Great or other officers are having interviews with one another,
though they may not be equal in rank,
if the host reverence (the greater worth of) the guest,
he should first bow to him;
and if the guest revernce the (greater worth of) the host,
he should first bow.
11. 23. In all cases but visits of condolence on occasion of a death,
and seeing the ruler of one's state,
the parties should be sure to return the bow, each of the other.
When a Great officer has an interviwew with the ruler of (another) state,
the ruler should bow in acknowledgement of the honour (of the message he brings);
when an officer has an interview with a Great officer (of that state),
the latter should bow to him in the same way.
When two meet for the first time in their own state, (on the return of one from some mission),
the other, as host, should bow in acknowledgement (of the service).
A ruler does not bow
to a (simple) officer;
but if he be of a different state,
he should bow to his bow.
A Great officer
should return the bow of any one of his officers,
however mean may be his rank.
12. 24. The ruler of a state, in the spring hunting, will not surround a marshy thicket,
nor will Great officers try to surprise a whole herd,
nor will (other) officers take young animals or eggs.
12. 25. In bad years,
when the grain of the season is not coming to maturity,
the ruler at his meals will not make the (usual) offering of the lungs,
nor will his horses be fed on grain.
His special road will not be kept clean and swept,
nor even at sacrifices will his musical instruments be suspended one their stands.
Great officers will not eat large grained millet;
and (other) officers will not have music even at their drinkings.
12. 26. Without some (sad) cause,
the ruler will not let the gems (pendent from his girdle) leave his person,
nor a Great officer remove his music-stand,
13. 27. When an officer presents anything to the ruler of his state,
and another day
the ruler asks him,
'Where did you get that?'
he will bow twice with his head to the ground, and afterwards reply.
14. 28. When a Great officer wishes to g beyond the boundaries (of the state) on private business,
he must ask leave,
and on his return
must present some offering.
An (inferior) officer in similar circumstances,
must (also) ask leave,
and when he comes back,
must announce his return.
If the ruler condole with them on their toils,
they should bow.
If he asks about their journey,
15. 29. When the ruler of a state (is proposing to) leave it,
they should (try to) stop him, saying,
'Why are you leaving the altars of the spirits of the land and grain?'
(In the similar case of) a Great officer,
they should say,
'Why are you leaving your acestral temple?'
In that of an (inferior) officer,
they should say,
'Why are you leaving the graves (of your ancestors)?'
A ruler should die for his altars;
a Great officer, with the host (he commands);
16. 30. As ruling ove all, under the sky,
(the king) is called 'The son of Heaven.'
As recieving at court the feudal princes,
assigning (to all) their diffierent offices, giving out (the laws and ordinances of) the government, and employing the services of the able,
he styles himself, 'I, the one man.'
16. 31. When he ascends by the easternsteps, and presides at a sacrifice,
if it be personal to himself and his family, his style is, 'I, so-and-so, the filial king;'
if it be external to himself, 'I, so-and-so, the inheriting king.'
When he visits the feudal princes,
and sends to make announcement (of his presence) to the spirits (of the hills and streams),
it is said, 'Here is he, so-and-so, who is king by (the grace of) Heaven.'
16. 32 His death is announced in the words,
'The king by (the grace of Heaven) has fallen.'
In calling back his spirit, they say,
'Return, O son of Heaven.'
When announcement is made (to all the states) of the mourning for him,
it is said, 'The king by (the grace of) Heaven has gone far on high.'
When his place is given to him in the ancestral temple,
and his spirit-tablet is set up,
he is styled on it, 'the god.'
16. 33. The son of Heaven, while he has not left off his mourning,
calls himself, 'I, the little child.'
While alive, he is so styled;
1. 1. The son of Heaven has his queen,
his help-mates,
his women of family,
and h is ladies of honour.
(These) constituted his wife
and concubines.
2. 2. The son of Heaven appoint the officers of Heaven's intuition,
the preceedence among them belonging to the six grandees:
- the Grand-governor;
the Grand-minister of the ancestral temple;
the Grand-historiographer;
the Grand-minister of prayers;
the Grand-minister of justice;
and the Grand-diviner.
Theses are the guardians and superintendents of the six departments of the statutes.
2. 3. The five (administrative) officers of the shon of Heaven are:
- the minister of instruction;
the minister of war;
the minister of works;
the ministerof offices;
and the minister of crime.
These five preside over the multitude in (each of) their five charges.
2. 4. The six treasuries of the son of Heaven
are under the charge of superintendent of the land;
the superintendent of the woods;
the superintendent of the waters;
the superintendent of the grass;
the superintendent of articles of employment;
and the superintendent of wares.
These preside over the six departments of their charges.
2. 5. The six manufactureers of the son of Heaven
are under the care of (the superintendents of) the workers in earth;
the workers in metal;
the workers in stone;
the workers in wood;
the workers in (the skins of) animals;
and the workers in twigs.
2. 6. When the five officers give in their contributions,
they are said to 'present their offerings.'
3. 7. Chief among the five officers
are the presidents,
to whom belong the oversight of quarters (of the kingdom).
In any message from tem transmitted to the son of Heaven,
they are styled 'ministers of the son of Heaven.'
If they are of the same surname as he,
he styles them 'paternal uncles;'
if of a different surname, 'maternal uncles.'
To the feudal princes, they designate themselves,
'the ancients of the son of Heaven.'
Outside (their own states), they are styled 'duke;'
in their states, 'ruler.'
3. 8. The head prince in each of the nine provinces,
on entering the state of the son of Heaven, is styled 'pastor.'
If he be of the same surname as himself,
the son of Heaven calls him 'my paternal uncle;'
if he be of a different surname, 'my maternal uncle.'
Outside (his own state) he is called 'marquis;'
in it, 'ruler.'
3. 9. The (chiefs) among (the wild tribes of) the Yi on the east, the Ti on the north, the Zung on the west, and the Man on the south,
however great (their territories), are called 'counts.'
In his own territories each one calls himself, 'the unworthy one;'
outside them, 'the king's ancient.'
3. 10. Any one of the princelets of their various tracts,
n entering the state of the son of Heaven, is styled 'such and such a person.'
Outside it he is called 'count,'
4. 11. When the son of Heaven stands with his back to the screen with axe-head figures on it,
and the princes present themselves before him with their faces to the north,
this is called kin (the autumnal audience).
When he stands at the (usual) point (of reception) between the door and the screen,
and the dukes have their faces towards the east,
and the feudal princes theirs towards the west,
this is called Khao (the spring audience).
4. 12. When feudal princes see one another at a place and time not agreed on beforehand, the interview is called 'a meeting.'
When they do so in some open place agreed on beforehand, it is called 'an assembly'
When one prince sends a Great officer to ask abvout another, it is called 'a message of friendly inquiry.'
When there is a binding to mutual faith, it is called 'a solemn declaration.'
When they use a victim, it is called 'a covenant.'
4. 13. When a feudal prince is about to be introduced to the son of Heaven, he is announced as, 'your subject so-and-so, prince of such-and-such a state.'
He speaks of himself to the people
as 'the man of little virtue.'
4. 14. If he be in mourning (for his father),
he is styled 'the rightful eldest son, and orphan;'
if he be taking part in a sacrifice
in his ancestral temple, 'the filial son, the prince of such-and-such a state, prince so-and-so.'
If it be another sacrifice elsewhere, the style is, 'so-and-so, prince of such-and-such a state, the distant descendant.'
4. 15. His death is describe by the character hung (disappeared).
In calling back (his spirit), they say, 'Return, sir so-and-so.'
When he has been interred
and (his son) is presented to the son of Heaven, the interview, (though special), is said to be 'of the same kind as the usual interviews.'
The honorary title given to him is (also) said to be 'after the usual fashion.'

5. 17. The demeanour of the son of Heaven should be characterized by majesty;
of the princes, by gravity;
of the Great officers, by a regulated composure;
if (inferior) officers, by an easy alertness;
6. 18. The partner of the son of Heaven is called 'the queen;'
of a feudal prince, 'the helpmate;'
of a Great officer, 'the attendant;'
of an (inferior) officer, 'the serving woman;'
and of a common man, 'the mate.'

and their honourable women,
(which) were their mates
and concubines.

'the aged servant;'
and before the prince (of another state),
'the small and unworthy ruler.'

'the small maid.'
From the honourable women downwards,
(each member of the harem) called herself 'your handmaid.'

entering the state of the son of Heaven,
was called 'the officer of such-and-such (a state), '
and styled himself 'your subsidiary minister.'
Outside (his own state), he was called 'sir;'
and in that state, 'the ancient of our poor ruler.'

A feudal prince should not be called by his name, while alive.

1. 1. According to the rules of propriety for a minister,

18. At the mourning rites for Yen Yuan,
some of the flesh of the sacrifice at the end of (?two) years
was sent to Confucius, who went out and recieved it.
On re-entering
he played his lute, and afterwards ate it.
19. Confucius was standing (once) with his disciples,
having his hands joined across his breast, and the right hand uppermost.
They also all placed their right hands uppermost.
He said to them,
'You do so from your wish to imitate me,
but I place my hands so, because I am in mourning for an elder sister.'
On this they all placed their left hands uppermost (according to the usual fashion).
20. Confucius rose early (one day),
and with his hands behind him, and trailing his staff,
moved slowly about near the door,
singing -
'The great mountain must crumble;
The strong beam must break;
The wise man must wither away like a plant.'
Having tus sung, he entered
and sat down opposite the door.
Tze.kung had heard him, and said,
'If the grea mountain crumble,
to what should I look up?
If the strong beam break, (On what shall I lean)?
If the wise man wither like a plant, whom shall I imitate?
The Master, I am afraid, is going to be ill.'
He then hastened into the house.
The Master said,
'Thze,
what makes you so late?
Under the souvereigns of Hsia, the body was dressed and coffined at the top of the steps on the east,
so that it was where the desceased used to go up (as master of the house).
The people of Yin performed the same ceremony between the two pillars,
so that the steps for the host were on one side of the corpse, and those for the guest on the other.
The people of Kau perform it a tt he top of the western steps,
reating the desceased as if he were a guest.
I am a man (descended from the house) of Yin,
and last night I
dreamt that I was sitting with the offerings to the dead by my side between the two pillars.
Intelligent kings do not arise;
and what one under heaven is able to take me as his Master?
I apprehend I am going to die.'
With this he took to his bed, was ill for several days, and died.
21. At the mourning rites for Confucius,
the disciples were in perplexity as to what deress they should wear.
Tze-kung said,
'Formerly, when the Master was mourning for Yen Yuan,
he acted in other respects as if he were mourning for a son,
but wore no mourning dress.
He did the same in the case of Tze-lu.
Let us mourn for the Master,
as if we were mourning for a father, but wear no mourning dress.'
22. At the mourning for Confucius,
Kung-hsǐ Khih made the ornaments of commemoration.
As the adornments of the coffin,
there were the wall-like curtains, the fan-like screens, and the cords at its sides,
after the manner of Kau.
There were the flags with their toothed edges,
after the manner of Yin;
and there were the flag-staffs bound with white silk, and long streamers pendent from them,
after the manner of Hsia.
23. At the mourning for Tze-kang,
Kung-ming I made the ornaments of ommemoration.
There was a tent-like pall, made of plain silk of a carnation colour,
with clusters of ants at the four corners,
(as if he had been) an officer of Yin.
24. Tze-hsia asked Confucius saying,
'How should (a son) conduct himself with reference to the man who has killed his father or mother?'
The Master said,
'He should sleep on straw, with his shiled for a pillow; he should not take office;
he must be determined not to live with the slayer under the same heaven.
If he meet with him in the market-place or the court,
he sould not have to go back for his weapon, but (instantly) fight with him.'
'Allow me to ask,'
said (the other), 'how one should do with reference to the man who has slain his brother?'
'He may take office,' was the reply,
'but not in the same state with the slayer;
if he bve sent on a mission by his ruler's orders,
though he may then meet with the man, he should not fight with him.'
'And how should one do,'
continued Tze-hsia, 'in the case of a man who has slain one of his paternal cousins?'
Confucius said,
'He should not take the lead (in the avenging).
If he whom it chiefly concerns is able to do that,
he should support him from behind, with his weapon in his hand.'
25. At the mourning rites for Confucius,
is disciples all wore their head-bands of sackcloth, when they went out.
For one of their own number, they wore them in the house (when condoling),
but not when they went out.
26. Keeping (the ground about) their graves clear of grass
was not a practice of antiquity.
27. Tze-lu said,
'I heard the Master say
that in the rites of mourning,
exceeding grief with deficient rites
is better than littel demonstration of grief with superabounding rites;
and that in those of sacrifice,
exceeding reverence with deficient rites
better than an excess of rites with but little revernce.'
28. Tseng-Tze having gone on a visit of condolence to Fu-hsia,
the chief mourner had already presented the sacrifice of departure,
and removed the offerings.
He caused the bier, however, to be pushed back to its former place,
and made the women come down (again), after which (the visitor) went through his ceremony.
The disciples who accompanied Tseng-tze asked him
if this proceeding were according to rule,
and he said,
'The sacrifice at starting is an important matter.
and why
might he not bring (the bier) back, and let it rest (for a while)?'
The disciples further asked
the same question of Tze-yu,
who said,
'The rice and precious shell are put into the mouh of the corpse under the window (of the western chamber);
the slighter dressing is done inside the door,
and the more complete one at (the top of ) the eastern steps;
the coffining takes place at the guests' place;
he sacrifice at starting in the courtyard;
and the interment at the grave.
The proceedings go on in this way to what is more remote,
and hence in the details of mourning there is a constant advance and no receeding.'
When Tseng-tze heard of this reply, he said,
'This is a much better account
than I have of the going forth to offer the sacrifice of departure.'
29. Tseng-tze went on a visit of condolence, wearing his fur robe over the silk one,
while Tze-yu went, wearing the silk one over his fur.
Tseng-tze, pointing to him, and calling the attention of the others, said,
'That man
as the reputation of being well versed in ceremonies,
how is it that he comes to condole with his silk robe displayed over his fur one?'
(By-and-by), when the chief mourner had finished the slighter dressing of the corpse,
he bared his breast and tied up his hair with sackcloth,
on which Tze-yu hastened out,
and (soon) came back, wearing his fur robe over the silk, and a girle of sackcloth.
Tseng-tze, on this said,
'I was wrong,
I was wrong.
That man was right.'
30. When Tze-hsia was introduced (to the Master) after he had put off the mourning (for his parents),
a lute was given to him.
He tried to tune it, but could hardly do so;
he touched it, but brought no melody from it.
He rose up and said,
'I have not yet forgotten my grief.
The ancient kings framed the rules of ceremony,
and I dare not go beyond them'
When a lute was given to Tze-kang
in the same circumstances,
he tried to tune it, and easily did so;
he touched it, and brought melody from it.
He rose up and said,
'The ancient kings framed the rules of ceremony,
and I do not dare not to come up to them.'
31. At the mourning rites for Hui-tze, who had been minister of Crime,
Tze-yu (went to condole), wearing for him a robe of sackcloth, and a headband made of the product of the male plant.
Wan-tze (the brother of for Hui-tze), wishing to decline the honour, said,
'You condescend to be the associate of my younger brother,
and now further condescend to wear this mourning;
I wenture to decline the honour.'
Tze-yu said,
'It is in rule;'
on which Wen-Tze returned an continued his wailing.
Tze-yu then hastened and took his place among the officers (of the family);
but Wen-tze also declined this honour, and said,
'You condescend to be the associate of my younger brother,
and now further condescend to wear for him this mourning,
and to come and take part in the mourning rites;
I venture to decline the honour.'
Tze-yu said,
'I beg firmly to request you to allow me (to remain here).'
Wa(n)-(?)ze then returned,
and supporting the rightful son to take his position with his face to the south, said,
'You condescend to be the associate of my younger brother,
and now you further condescend to wear this mourning for him,
and to come and take part in the rites;
dare Hu but return to his (proper) place?'
Tze-yu on this hastened to take his position among the guests.
32. At the mourning rites for the general Wa(n)-(?)ze,
when the first year's mourning was at an end,
there came a man from Yueh on a visit of condolence.
the chief mourner, wearing the long robe (assumed on the completion of the first year's mourning), and the cap worn before that,
wailed for him in the ancestral temple,
with the tears urunning from his eyes and the rheum from his nose.
Tze-yu saw it, and said,
'The son of general Wa(n) is not fa from being (a master of ceremonies).
In his observances at this time, for which there is no special rule,
his proceeding is correct.'
33. The giving of the name in childhood,
of the designation at the capping,
the title of elder uncle or younger uncle at fifty,
and of the honourary title after death,
was the practice of the Kau dynasty.
33... The wearing of the sackcloth headbands and girdles, to express the real (feeling of the heart);
33... the digging of a hole in the middle of the appartment (over which) to wash (the corpse);
taking down the (tiles of the) furnace, and placing them at the feet (of it);
and at the interment
pulling down (part of the wall on the west of the door of) the anceestral temple,
so as to pass by the upper side (of the altar to the spirit) of the way, and issue by the great gate;
- these were the practices of the Yin dynasty,
and the learners (in the school of Confucius) followed them.
34. When the mother of Tze-liu died,
(his younger brother) Tze-shih asked for the means (to provide what was necessary for the mourning rites).
Tze-liu said,
'How shall we get them?'
'Let us sell (the concubines), the mothers of uor half-brothers,'
said the other.
'How can we sell the mothers of other men
to bury our own mother?' was the reply.
'that cannot be done.'
After the burial,
Tze-shih wished to take what remained of the money and other things contributed towards their expenses, to provide sacrificial vessels;
but Tze-liu said,
'Neither can that be done.
I have heard
that the superior man will not enrich his family by means of his mourning.
Let us distribute it among the poor of our brethren.'
35. A superior man said,
'He who has given counsel to another about his army
should die with it when it is defeated.
He who has given counsel about the country or its capital
should perish with it when it comes into peril.'
36. Kung-shu Wen-tze ascended themound of Hsia,
with Ku Po-yu following him.
Wen-tze said,
'How pleasant is this mound!
I should like to be buried here when I die.'
Ku Po-yu said,
'You may find pleasure in such a thought,
but allow me (to go home) before you say anything more about it.'
37. There was a man of Pien
who wept like a child on the death of his mother.
Confucius said,
'This is grief indeed,
but it would be difficult to continue it.
Now the rules of ceremony
require to be handed down,
nd to be prepetuated.
Hence the wailing and leaping are subject to fixed regulations.'
38. When the mother of Shu-sun Wu-shu died,
and the slighter dressing had been completed,
the bearers went out at the door (of the apartment) with the corpse.
When he had himself gone out at the door,
he bared his arms, throwing down also his cap, and binding his hair with sackcloth.
Tze-yu said (in derision),
'He knows the rules!'
39. (When a ruler was ill),
the high chamberlain supported him on the right,
and the assigner of positions at audiences did so on the left.
When he died these two officers lifted (the corpse).
40. There are the husband of a maternal cousin
and the wife of a maternal uncle;
- that these should wear mourning for each other
has not been said by any superior man.
Some one says, 'If they have eaten together from the same fireplace, the three monts' m ourning should be worn.'
41. It is desirable that affairs of mourning
should be gone about with urgency,
and festive affairs
n a leisurely way.
Hence, though affairs of mourning require urgency,
they should not go beyond the prescribed rules;
and though festive affairs may be delayed,
they should not be transacted negligently.
Hurry therefore (in the former) becomes rudeness,
and to much ease (in the latter) shows a small man.
The superior man will conduct himself in them as they severally require.
42. A superior man is ashamed to prepare (beforehand)
all that he may require in discharging his mourning rites.
What can be made in one or towo days,
he does not prepare (beforehand).
43. The mourning
worn for the so of a brother should be the same as for one's own son:
the object being to bring him still nearer to one's self.
An elder brother's wife and his younger brother do not wear mourning for each other:
the object being to maintain the distance between them.
Slight m ournig is worn for an aunt, and an elder or younger sister, (when they have been married);
the reason being that there are those who recieved them from us, and will render to them the full measure of observance.
1. When the Master was eating by the side of one who had mourning rites in hand,
he never ate to the full.
2. Tseng-tze was standing with (another) visitor by the side of the door (of their house of entertainment),
when a companion (of the other) came hurrying out.
'Where are you going?'
said Tseng-tze;
and the man replied,
'My father is dead,
and I am going to wail for him in the lane.'
'Return to your apartment,'
was the reply,
'and wail for him there.'
(the man did so), and Tseng-tze made him a visit of condolence, standing with his face to the north.
3. Confucius said,
'In dealing with the dead, if we treat them as if they were entirely dead,
that would show a lack of affection, and should not be done;
or, if we treat them as if they were entirely alive,
that would show a want of wisdom, and should not be done.
On this account
the vessels of bamboo (used in connexion with the burial of the dead) are not fit for actual use;
those of earthenware cannot be used to wash in;
hose of wood are incapable of being carved;
the lutes are strung, but not evenly;
the pandean pipes are complete, but not in tune;
the bells and musical stones are there, but they have no stands.
They are called vessels to the eye of fancy;
that is, (the dead) are thus treated as if they were spiritual intelligences.'
4. Yu-tze asked Tseng-tze
if he had ever questioned the Master about (an officer's) losing his place.
'I heard from him,' was the reply,
'that the officer in such a case would wish to become poor quickly,
(just as)we should wish to decay away quickly when we have died.'
Yu-tze said,
'These are not the words of a superior man,'
'I heard the m from the Master,
returned Tseng-tze.
Yu-tze repeated
that they were not the words of a superior man,
and the other affirmed
that both he and Tze-yu had heard them.
'Yes, yes,'
said Yu-tze,
'but them Master must have spokken them with a special reference.'
Tseng-tze reported Yu-tze's words to Tze-yu,
who said,
'How very
like his words are to those of the Master!
Formerly, when the Master was staying in Sung,
he saw that Hwan, the minister of war, had been for three years having a stone coffin made for himself
without it being finished,
The master said,
"What extravagance!
It would be better that when dead he should quickly decay away."
It was with reference to hwan, the minister of War, that he said,
'"We should wishd to decay away quickly when we die."
When Nan-kung King-shu returned (to the state),
he made it a point to carry his treasures with him in his carriage when he went to court,
on which the Master said,
"Such an amount of property!
It would have been better for him, when he lost his office, to make haste to become poor."
It was with reference to Nan-kung King-shu that he said
that "We should work to become poor quickly, when we have lost office."'
Tseng-tze reported theses words of Tsi-yu to Yu-tze,
who said,
'Yes,
I did say
that these words were not the words of the Master.'
When the other asked him
how he knew it,
he said,
'The Master made an ordinance in Kung-tu
that the inner coffin should be four inches thick,
and the outer five.
By this I knew that he did not wish that the dead should decay away quickly.
And former ly, when he had lost the office of minister of Crime in Lu,
and was about to go to King,
he first sent Tze-hsia there,
and after wards Zan Yu.
By this I knew that he did not wish to become poor quickly.'
5. When Kwang-tze of Kha(n died,
announcement of the event was sent to Lu.
They did not want to wail for him there,
but duke Mu called Hsien-tze, and consulted him.
He said,
'In old times, no message from Great officers,
not even such as were accompanied by a bundle of dried meat, went out beyond the boundaries of their states.
though it had been wished to wail for them,
how could it have been done?
Nowadays the Great officers
share in the measures of government throughout the middle states.
Though it may be wished not to wail for one,
how can it be avoided?
I have heard, moreover,
that there are two grounds for the wailing;
one from love,
and one from fear.'
the duke said,
'Very well;
but how is the thing to be managed in this case?'
Hsien-(?)ze said,
'I would ask you to wail for him in the temple of (a family of) adifferent surname;'
and hereon the duke and he wailed for Kwang-(?)ze in (the temple of) the Hsien family.
6. Kung Hsien said to (?)ang-(?)ze,
'Under the souvereigns of the Hsia dynasty, they used (at burials) the vessels which were such only to the eye of fancy,
intimating to the people that (the dead) had no knowledge.
Under the Yin they used the (ordinary) sacrificial vessels,
intimating to the people that (the dead) had knowledge.
Under the Kau we use both,
intimationg to the people that the thing is doubtful.'
(?)ang-(?)ze replied,
'It is not so!
What are vessels (only) to the eye of fancy
are for the shades (of the departed);
the vessels of sacrifice
are those of men;
how should those ancients
have treated their parents as if they were dead?'
7. An elder brother of Kung-shu Mu, by the same mother but a different father, having died,
he asked (?)ze-yu (whether he should go into mourning for him),
and was answered,
'Perhaps you should do so for the period of nine months.'
A brother, similarly related to Ti Yi having died,
he consulted (?)ze-hsia in the same way,
and was answered,
'I have not heard anything about it before,
but the people of Lu wear the one year's mourning in such a case.'
Ti I did so,
and the present practice of wearing that mourning
arose from his question.
8. When (?)ze-sze's mother died in Wei,
Liu Zo said to him,
'You, Sir,
are the descendant of a sage.
From all quarters they look to you for an example in ceremonies;
let me advice you to be careful in the matter.'
(?)ze-sze said,
'Of what have I to be careful?
I have heard
that when there are certain ceremonies to be observed,
and he has not the necessary means for them,
a superior man does not observe them,
and neither does he do so,
when there are the ceremonies,
and he has the means,
but the time is not suitable,
of what have I to be careful?'
9. Hsien-(?)ze So said,
'I have heard
that the ancients amde no diminution (in the degeres of mourning on any other ground);
but mourned for every one above and below according to his relationship.
thus Wa(n, the earl of Tha(ng), wore the year's mourning for Maeng-hu,)
who was his uncle,
and the same for Maeng Phǐ,
whose uncle he was.'
10. Hou Mu said,
'I heard Hsien-(?)ze say
about the rites of mourning,
that (a son)
should certainly think deeply an long about them all,
and that (for instance) in buying the coffin he should see that, inside and outside, it be (equally) well completed.
When I die, let it be so also with me.'
11. (?)a(ng)-(?)ze said,
'Until the corpse has its ornaments put on it,
they curtain the hall;
and after the slighter dressing the curtain is removed.'
Kung-liang-(?)ze said,
'Husband and wife are at first all in confusion,
and therefore the hall is curtained off.
After the slighter dressing, the curtain is removed.'
12. With regard to the offerings to the dead at the time of the slighter dressing,
(?)ze.yu said
that they should be placed on the east (of the corpse).
(?)ang-(?)ze said,
'They should be placed on the west,
on the mat there at the time of the dressing.'
The placing of the offerings on the west at the time of the slighter dressing
was an error of the later times of Lu.
13. Hsien-(?)ze said,
'To have the mourning robe of coarse dolchos cloth, and the lower garment of fine linen with a wide texture,
was not the way of antiquity.'
14. When (?)ze-phu died,
the wailers called out his name Mieh.
(?)ze-kao said,
'So rude and uncultivated are they!'
On this they changed their style.
15. At the mournig rites for the mother of Tu Khiao
one was employed in the house to assist (the son in the ceremonies)
which was accounted a careless omission.
16. The master said,
'As soon as death occurs,
(the embers of the family) should change their lambskin furs and dark-coloured caps,
though they may do nothing more.'
The Master did not pay a visit of condolence
in these articles of dress.
17. (?)ze-yu asked about the articles to be provided four the mourning rites,
and the Master said,
'They should be according to the means of the family.' [經典釋文：有亡：皇如字，無也。一音無。下同。]
(?)ze-yu urged,
'How can a family that has means and one that has nt have things done in the same way?'
'Where there are means,'
was the reply,
'let there be no exceeding of the prescribed rites.
If there be a want of means,
let the body be lightly covered from head to foot,
and forthwith buried,
the coffin being simply by means of ropes.
Who in such a case will blame the procedure?'
18. Pa(n,) superintendent of officer's registries, informed (?)ze-yu
of his wish to dress his dead on the couch.
'You may,'
said (?)ze-yu.
When Hsien-(?)ze heard of this, he said,
'How arrogant is the old gentleman!
He takes it on himself to allow men in what is the proper rule.'
19. At the burial of his wife, duke Hsiang of Sung
placed (in the grave) a hundred ars of vinegar and pickles.
(?)a(ng) (?)ze said,
'they are called ''vessels only to the eye of fancy,''
and yet he filled them!'
20. After the mourning rites for Ma(ng) Hsien-(?)ze,
the chief minster of his family made his subordinates return their money-offerings to all the donors.
The Master said
that such a thing was allowable.
21. About the reading of the list of the material contributions (towards the service of a funeral),
(?)a(ng)-(?)ze said,
'It is not an ancient practice;
it is a second announcement (to the departed)!'
22. When Khaeng-(?)ze Kao was lying ill,
Khing I went to see him,
and asked his (parting) commands, saying,
'Your disease, Sir, is severe.
If I should go on to be the great illness,
what are we to do?'
(?)ze-Kao said,
'I have heard
that in life we should be of use to others,
and in death should do them no harm.
Although I have been of no use to others during my life,
shall I do them any harm by my death?
When I am dead,
choose a piece of barren ground, and bury me there.'
23. (?)ze-hsia asked the Master
(how one should deport himself) during the mourning for the ruler's mother or wife, (and the reply was)
'In sitting and stopping with others, in his conversation, and when eating and drinking, he should appear to be at ease.'
24. When a stranger-visitor arrived,
and had nowhere to lodge,
the Master would say,
'While he is alive, let him lodge with me.
Should he die, I will see to his coffining.'
25. Kwo-(?)ze kao said,
'Burying
means hiding away;
and that hiding (of the body)
is from a whish that men should not see it.
Hence
there are the clothes sufficient for an elegant covering;
the coffin round about the clothes;
the shell all around the coffin;
and the earth all around the shell.
And shall we farther raise a mound over the grave and plant it with trees?'
26. At the mourning for Confucius,
there came a man from Yen to see (what was done),
and lodged at (?)ze-hsia's.
(?)ze-hsia said to him,
'If it had been the sage's conducting a burial, (there would have been something to see);
but what is there to see
in our burying the sage?
Formerly the Master made some remarks to me, saying,
"I have seen some mounds made like a raised hall;
others like a dyke on a river's bank;
others like the roof of a large house;
nd others in the shape of an axe-head."
We ahve followed the axe-shape,
making what is called the horse-mane mound.
